1.content:
Southern Pennsylvania
March 2003

The snow was only just starting as Brian Sheppard left the hospital with his wife and infant daughter. The two were emotional wrecks as they made their way into the hospital’s parking garage. Deanna, their 13-month-old daughter, had spent the last four days in the hospital after experiencing several seizures within a short amount of time. This was the third such occurrence since Deanna had been diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer six months earlier.

Once they arrived at their car, Brian unlocked the doors so Gloria could place Deanna in her car seat. As the two of them got in the car, Gloria looked at her husband and said, “What are we going to do, Brian?” barely holding it together, Gloria continued, “The news just keeps getting worse; and I don’t want to lose our little girl.”

Brian and Gloria had been told the previous night that Deanna’s increasing seizures meant that her condition was becoming worse. Unless a miracle happened within the next few months, it was likely that Deanna wouldn’t survive. “I wouldn’t throw the towel in just yet, Gloria; there are still some possible treatments that we can try.” Patting his jacket pocket, Brian said, “The doctor gave me some information about some experimental treatments that she thinks could work.”

“How dare you accuse me of throwing in the towel.” Staring at her husband, her emotions getting the better of her, Gloria yelled,
“Don’t you dare, for one second, think that I’m giving up on saving Deanna’s life.”

Brian came close to losing control himself; the stress of the last few days having gotten to him as well. However, he managed to stay calm, “I’m sorry Gloria, I-I didn’t mean it like that.” Sighing as he went to turn the car on, he continued, “We’ve both been under a lot of pressure recently.”

Gloria remained silent as Brian drove out of the parking garage; waiting a few minutes before responding. “I just wish there was something we could do; something we haven’t thought of yet.”

Brian and Gloria spent the 20-minute ride to their apartment complex in silence as they were both too emotionally drained to speak. Pulling into their parking space Brian caught sight of their neighbors Chris and Maggie Johnson walking down the sidewalk with some groceries.

Brian threw a half-hearted wave at them as he turned off the car; stepping out as they approached. The Johnson's had moved into the complex a few weeks after the Sheppard’s learned of Deanna’s diagnosis; Chris was an Anthropology intern at a local museum while Maggie was a social worker.

Gloria wasn’t in the mood to chat, so she silently walked past with Deanna. Maggie looked at Brian as he slowly approached them; the look on his face telling her everything she needed to know. “What did the doctors say, Brian?”

“They said that Deanna’s condition has progressed to where they can’t do anything for her.” Struggling to keep his composure, Brian continued, “Unless a miracle happens, she’s got maybe 2 months to live.”

In the five months they’d known each other both Chris and Maggie had grown close to the Sheppard's; and neither of them like to see their friends so emotionally distraught. As he placed a sympathetic hand on Brian’s shoulder, Chris said, “If there’s anything we can do to help, just let us know.”

“You’ve both already gone above and beyond; neither myself or Gloria can thank you for everything you’ve done.” Briefly covering his mouth with a hand, Brian said, “If anything else comes up, I’ll be...we’ll let you know.”

The three of them spoke for a few minutes until the cool temperatures finally got to them. After saying their goodbyes Chris and Maggie watched Brian as he went upstairs to check on Gloria. As they continued to their apartment, Chris turned to Maggie and saw that she was deep in thought. “Is something wrong, Maggie?”

Digging keys from her pocket, Maggie looked towards Chris and said, “We have to do something to help Brian and Gloria.” Sighing as she opened the door to their apartment, Maggie continued, “They’ve been nothing but kind to us since we arrived.”

Stepping inside the apartment, Chris shut the door and walked towards a strange cube-shaped device on a nearby counter. There was an almost imperceptible hum from the device after Chris pressed a series of buttons. Walking into the kitchen after his wife, Chris said, “What you’re suggesting would violate every rule in the book.” Leaning up against the counter, Chris continued,
“Even if that weren’t true; I don’t think Brian and Gloria can handle something of that magnitude.”

“That’s where you’re wrong, Chris; I have faith that they’re ready.” Closing the fridge as she turned to her husband, Maggie said, “Besides, what’s the worst that could happen if they’re not ready?”

“Do you really need to ask that question?” Looking at his wife, Chris continued, “If the government were to ever find out about us, they’d lock us away and do experiments on us.”

“You’ve really got to stop watching those old sci-fi films.” Taking a step towards the kitchen door, Maggie said, “In all our dealings with the Sheppard's, when have they ever acted like the humans in those movies.”

At this point Chris knew better than to try and talk Maggie down; she was going to go through with whatever she was planning regardless of what he thought. Following her, Chris said, “I still don’t think this is smart; but I’ve never been able to talk you out of doing something you set your mind to.” Standing at the door, he said, “I’ll get everything ready while you go invite them over for drinks or something.”

****************************


An hour went by before Brian and Gloria decided to head across the hall to their neighbor’s apartment. After checking on Deanna for the 10th time in the 15 minutes, Gloria grabbed the baby monitor and went to meet Brian at the door. “I don’t know if now is the right time for this, Brian.” walking out into the hall, Gloria said, “We just got Deanna home, I think we need to spend time with her.”

“Look it’s not ideal, I know; but Chris and Maggie are our friends.” Closing the door behind him, Brian said, “They’re concerned about our well being, and rightly so.”

Maybe it was because they were talking louder than normal, or perhaps he’d been close to the door; but Chris had the door open before Brian could even knock. “Hey guys, come on in and have a seat.” Stepping to the side, he said, “Maggie’s just finishing up in the bedroom; she’ll be right out.”

As the two of them walked into the apartment, Brian turned around in time to watch Chris close the door and head over to a small box situated on the counter. He’d seen it a couple times but never bothered to ask about it; until now that is. “Hey Chris; what exactly is that cube thing?”

Without even looking up from the device, Chris said, “It dampens noise within a preset area.”

“Seriously man, what is it?” certain that Chris was messing with him, Brian said, “I’ve never seen anything like that before.”

“Why don’t you guys sit down.” Walking past them, in a tone they’d never heard him give before, Chris said, “I promise everything will become clear soon enough.”

Brian and Gloria exchanged worried looks as they started to sit down – wondering what they were getting themselves into. They’d never felt in danger around Chris or Maggie, but something was causing them to become worried for their safety. “What exactly is going on here, Chris?”

Chris paced around the room for a moment as if he were deep in thought about something. After a few moments of silence, he turned towards the couch and said, “We haven’t known each other for long. But,” with a heavy sigh, Chris continued, “Maggie and I have come to see that you two are far more open minded then other members of your species.”

Brian and Gloria gave each other confused looks as they had no idea what Chris was saying. “What’s that supposed to mean, Chris?” turning to her friend, Gloria said, “Aren’t we the same species?”

“No Gloria, we’re not; but it’ll be easier if we just showed you.” Momentarily covering his mouth, Chris turned to the closed bedroom door and said, “Maggie, you can come out now.”

Brian and Gloria focused all their attention on the door as they heard movement from the other side. The door opened and they saw a strange figure, unlike anything they’d ever seen before, step out of the bedroom. Startled, Gloria clung tightly to Brian’s arm as the figure slowly approached them.

It was clearly female as they could see breasts underneath the outfit it was wearing. But that’s where the similarities ended; its skin was a blue-green color, its skull was elongated and, from what they could see, there were only 4 fingers on each of its hands.

In a panic, Brian and Gloria sprang to their feet and ran to the door; screaming as loud as their lungs allowed. Before they could even undo the first lock, the alien creature forced itself between them and the door.

If seeing a real live alien wasn’t shocking enough for them; what happened next certainly was. Looking at them, the creature said, “Calm down guys, everything is going to be fine.”

That was too much for Gloria to handle; she collapsed to the floor as Brian looked at the alien before him. “M-Maggie?”
1.title: The Beginning (Prologue, Part 1)

11.content:
With some help from Chris, Brian was able to carry Gloria over to the couch. As they waited for her to regain consciousness, Maggie cautiously approached Brian. “We figured you would be taken by surprise; but I didn’t expect Gloria to have that sort of reaction.”

“Yeah, well it’s not every day your neighbors reveal themselves to be aliens.” Looking over Maggie’s alien form, while trying to be as discrete as possible, Brian said, “It’s strange; I can still tell that it’s you in there.”

Putting on her best imitation of a model posing, Maggie said, “Our disguises are what we’d look like had we been born human.” Looking at Brian, Maggie said, “Yours in the 3rd species I’ve disguised myself as.”

Brian was about to ask more about that when Gloria started to stir. “I had the strangest dream, babe.” Slowly sitting up, Gloria said, “Chris and Maggie invited us over to for drinks; but Maggie turned out to be some...”

Gloria stopped as she became aware of her surroundings. Everything was going well until she saw the blue humanoid standing next to Chris; both looking on in concern. In stark contrast to just moments earlier, Gloria didn’t have much of a reaction. Cautiously approaching his wife, Brian said, “It wasn’t a dream, honey; Chris and Maggie really are...aliens.”

“We’re from a planet called Maltor Prime; about 25 lightyears from here.” Maggie cautiously approached her friend so as not to spook her. “Our species discovered your world 150 years ago; we’ve been sending fact-finding missions here ever since, studying your world and its inhabitants.”

Brian took a seat next to Gloria; although neither of them spoke a word. Sensing their trepidation, Chris pointed towards the cube on the counter, “You can speak freely here; even the most dedicated busybody would have to enter the apartment to hear what we say here."

Brian and Gloria exchanged looks; as the latter turned back towards Chris and Maggie. “Who...what are you?”

“As my wife said, we’re Maltorians.” Gesturing to Maggie as he spoke, Chris said, “Our true names are Q’uris and Ma’gi D’Pkeni.”

Brian and Gloria took a moment to process what they were hearing. Eventually, Brian said, “Why...why are you telling us this?”

“We thought it wise to tell you the truth; so you’d be more likely to believe what we’re about to tell you.”

“It’s no secret that we’ve all become close friends since our arrival.” Standing next to her husband, Ma’gi said, “We couldn’t bear to see the pain you two were experiencing; especially when we had the ability to do something about it.”

Gloria was starting to suspect where Ma’gi was heading with this; but didn’t want to get her hopes up. “What exactly are you saying?”

“We have the means to cure Deanna’s tumor; allowing her to grow up like any other child.” Focusing on Gloria, Ma’gi said, “That is; if you’ll let us.”

Gloria looked at her husband for a moment, seeing that he was also on the fence. Swallowing, Gloria turned back her friends and said, “Can we have a moment to discuss this...privately?”

"Of course; we’ll withdraw to the bedroom.” Taking his wife’s hand, Q’uris said, “Just knock when you’ve reached a decision.”

Brian waited until the door was closed before getting to his feet. Turning to his wife, he said, “Are we really considering this?”
“I don’t see that we have much choice, Brian.” Sighing, Gloria said, “They said they can heal Deanna."

Pacing around the room for a moment, Brian said, “Let’s say, for a moment, that we go through with this.” Looking towards Gloria, he said, “The doctors know what Deanna’s prognosis is; how will we explain a tumor just disappearing?”

“I’m sure we’ll figure it out; but frankly I don’t care.” Getting to her feet, Gloria said, “We’ve been giving a chance to save our daughter’s life; we’d be fools not to take it.”

“But what if it doesn’t work?” getting nervous, Brian said, “Just because it works on them is no guarantee it'll work on us."

“You accused me earlier of giving up on our daughter; now I can’t help but think that’s what you’re doing.” Looking at her husband, “Our best friends are offering to help us; and you want to turn them away because of how many fingers they have?"

Hearing Gloria put it that way, Brian couldn’t help but feel two inches tall. Gloria was right; they were nothing if not desperate, why wouldn’t they jump at the promise of a cure. With a sigh and a nod, Brian walked to the bedroom door and knocked. Once Q’uris opened the door, Brian said, “We’ll do it.”
11.title: The Explanation (Prologue, Part 2)

111.content:
Within minutes of announcing their decision, Brian and Gloria led Q’uris and Ma’gi across the hall to their apartment. The timing couldn’t have been better, because they found Deanna experiencing the beginning stages of a seizure. Once it stopped, Q'uris injected Deanna with a syringe full of a dark blue liquid.

As he gently placed Deanna back in her crib, Q’uris said, “It will take time before we know if the injection has done its job.”
Following Q’uris out of the bedroom, with Gloria beside him, Brian said, “How will we know if it worked?”

Q’uris gestured towards Ma’gi, who was waiting for the others in the living room. As she held up a small device, Q’uris explained, “What she’s holding functions much in the same way as the tricorder on Star Trek.” Taking a seat next to his wife, Q’uris said, “We’ll check Deanna’s condition every 20 minutes or so.”

Brian and Gloria both took seats across from their guests; with no one having any idea what to say. After a few moments of awkward silence, Ma’gi finally spoke up and said, “I’d imagine that you both have some questions?”

That one comment opened the floodgates as Brian and Gloria went ahead and bombarded their friends with endless questions. Brian was more interested in the big picture; asking what Maltor Prime was like (geologically younger than Earth, but similar in size). Gloria, for her part, asked generic questions. Focusing her attention on Ma’gi, she said, “What was the hardest thing for you to adjust to?”

“Oh, that’s easy; having hair.” Gesturing to her bald scalp, Ma’gi said, “Coming from a species with very little in the way of hair, I never realized how much of a hassle it would be; waking up with in in my face every morning, having to brush and clean it regularly.”

“Oh please.” Chuckling, Q’uris said, “Don’t you remember your first assignment?”

Ma’gi gave her husband a blank stare for a moment; before smacking her forehead with one hand, “Oh Chrestus, you’re right; I forgot about that.” Seeing the bemused looks on her friend’s faces, she continued, “For my first assignment after training, I was sent to observe this primitive, tribalistic, race of ape-like creatures near what you call the Pleiades. Apart from hunting and gathering, the big communal activity was picking nits off each other.”

That topic of discussion continued for a few more minutes until Q’uris went to check on Deanna. Brian and Gloria were cautiously optimistic until they heard Q’uris say, in a disturbing tone, “Guys, you may want to come in here.”

Brian and Gloria jumped to their feet; nearly colliding with each other as they ran into the bedroom. As they approached Deanna’s crib, they stopped in their tracks when they saw what had Q’uris so concerned. Deanna’s skin had taken on a light shade of blue and was slowly getting darker. If they looked close enough, Brian and Gloria would’ve noticed both of Deanna’s pinkies and little toes beginning to shrivel up.
111.title: The Injection (Prologue, Part 3)

1111.content:
Gloria was justifiably shocked at what she was seeing before her; after all, it wasn’t every day you saw your child undergo such a radical transformation. She was on the verge of lashing out in anger as Ma’gi rushed into the room. Looking towards her friends, Gloria said, “What’s happening to my baby?”

“This was an unforeseen complication.” Taking the scanner from Ma’gi, Q’uris slowly ran it over Deanna’s body. Looking up from the screen, he said, “It seems that Deanna is in the process of becoming a Maltorian.”

"You did this deliberately, didn’t you?” Filled with rage, Brian grabbed Q’uris by his shirt collar, “Why did you do this?”

“I can assure you we had no idea this would happen; as far as we knew the treatment would only cure her condition.” As he calmly removed Brian’s hands, Q’uris said, “If I had any untoward plans for your daughter, believe me when I say wouldn’t have been able to stop me. Even a Maltorian child has twice the strength of the stronger human.”

Coming around to stand next to her husband, Ma’gi said, “We wanted to give you your daughter back; we wouldn’t have suggested this if we thought this would happen. To do what you suggest would be against Chrestus."

Gloria moved towards the crib and picked up Deanna; finding that some of her har was already falling out. Holding her daughter in her arms, Gloria turned to Brian and said, “What do we do now?”

“Your society isn’t ready to know about our existence yet.” Q'uris replied. “As much as it pains me to suggest this; the only way to keep her safe is for us to bring her to Maltor Prime.”

“No.” his voice shaking, Brian said, “There has to be another way?”

“You’ve known me for months, Brian; but still you were ready to believe the worst about me.” Gesturing to Deanna, Q’uris said, “How do you think strangers would feel about Deanna?”

Brian said nothing. He only moved next to Gloria and touched his daughter's head, removing more of her hair. Turning to Ma’gi, Gloria said, "How soon will her head look like yours?"

“That won’t happen for many years, I’m afraid; it’s a function of puberty."

Brian and Gloria looked at Deanna in silence; watching as her skin was almost identical to Ma’gi. Although they knew it would hurt, they both knew what they had to do.
1111.title: Complications (Prologue, Part 4)
